Package com.penthera.virtuososdk.client.push

Class ADMReceiver

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.content.BroadcastReceiver
      • com.amazon.device.messaging.ADMMessageReceiver
        • com.penthera.virtuososdk.client.push.ADMReceiver
  • public class ADMReceiver
extends com.amazon.device.messaging.ADMMessageReceiver
    The ADM client on the device broadcasts events to this receiver. The receiver forwards these messages the ADMService to run in the background on older android devices or to the ADMJobMessageHandler on newer devices with background process restrictions You only need to create a different class if you want forward messages to your own implementation of an ADMService or ADMJobMessageHandler.
    See Also:
    ADMService, ADMJobMessageHandler

    • Constructor Detail

      • ADMReceiver

        public ADMReceiver()
        The default constructor. It calls super passing in ADMService.class and ADMJobMessageHandler.class as the parameters. If implementing you own receiver and service then pass your subclass of ADMService and ADMJobMessageHandler.class in the call to super.
        See Also:
        ADMService

      • ADMReceiver

        public ADMReceiver​(Class<? extends com.amazon.device.messaging.ADMMessageHandlerBase> aClass,
                   Class<? extends com.amazon.device.messaging.ADMMessageHandlerJobBase> aJobClass)
        Associates this ADMReceiver with the ADMService and ADMJobMessageHandlersubclass. If providing a subclass then your default constructor should call this to initialise the parent class.
        Parameters:
        aClass - Your ADMService subclass. When ADM receives a message for an instance of your app, it forwards the message content Intent to this class for processing on older android versions.
        aJobClass - Your ADMJobMessageHandler subclass When ADM receives a message for an instance of your app, * it forwards the message content Intent to this class for processing on newer android versions.
        See Also:
        ADMService, ADMJobMessageHandler
